meanings.definition: To insert, implant, or fix firmly into something else
meanings.sent1: The surgeon will engraft the new heart into the patient's chest.
meanings.sent2: She carefully engrafted the flower into the soil to help it grow.
meanings.sent3: Trying to engraft a banana peel onto a tree won't make a banana tree!
meanings.sent4: Her words engrafted hope into his heart, like a seed taking root.
meanings.sent5: The artist engrafted her signature onto the painting, making it uniquely hers.

meanings.definition: To establish or secure something firmly
meanings.sent1: The team worked hard to engraft their lead in the game.
meanings.sent2: He wanted to engraft his reputation as a reliable worker in the company.
meanings.sent3: Trying to engraft a smile on a grumpy cat's face is quite a challenge!
meanings.sent4: Her determination engrafted success into every project she undertook.
meanings.sent5: The roots of the tree engrafted deeply into the ground, providing stability.

meanings.definition: To incorporate or blend something into another thing
meanings.sent1: The chef will engraft the new flavors into the traditional recipe.
meanings.sent2: She wanted to engraft her personal style into the design of the house.
meanings.sent3: Trying to engraft a pop song into a classical music concert would be interesting!
meanings.sent4: His ideas engrafted seamlessly into the existing framework, enhancing it.
meanings.sent5: The artist engrafted elements of nature into her artwork, creating a beautiful harmony.
